messages.text:
So what's the current recommended way to start a Pluto notebook in a temporary environment? Is it to add a cell at the beginning like suggested in <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/142#issuecomment-685135043> or is there a way closer to what is suggested in <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/142#issuecomment-706373763>, i.e., maybe something like
```Pluto.run(;temp=true)```
Or something else entirely?

elements.text: So what's the current recommended way to start a Pluto notebook in a temporary environment? Is it to add a cell at the beginning like suggested in
or is there a way closer to what is suggested in
, i.e., maybe something like
Pluto.run(;temp=true)
Or something else entirely?

messages.text: Hey folks, I just started to use Pluto and it is a great experience so far :slightly_smiling_face:. I just had a question about debugging. Is it possible to add breakpoints in a cell? Like if I were running Debugger.jl, I would add the `@bp` macro and then it would drop to the command line in the cell. I am not sure if something like that is possible in Pluto yet, but I figured I would ask. Thanks.

elements.text: Hey folks, I just started to use Pluto and it is a great experience so far
. I just had a question about debugging. Is it possible to add breakpoints in a cell? Like if I were running Debugger.jl, I would add the
@bp
macro and then it would drop to the command line in the cell. I am not sure if something like that is possible in Pluto yet, but I figured I would ask. Thanks.

messages.text: Hey folks, just wanted to check if I am doing something wrong. I added a `@show`  statement in a loop to display the values as a pluto cell processes the code. But I am getting an error that I am not understanding. Here is a picture and here is the code.

elements.text: Hey folks, just wanted to check if I am doing something wrong. I added a
@show
statement in a loop to display the values as a pluto cell processes the code. But I am getting an error that I am not understanding. Here is a picture and here is the code.

messages.text:
```begin
n2 = 10
v = 0.0
for i in 1:n2
	@show v
	v = ((n2-1)/n)*v + (1/n)*rand()
end

end```

elements.text:
begin
n2 = 10
v = 0.0
for i in 1:n2
	@show v
	v = ((n2-1)/n)*v + (1/n)*rand()
end

end

messages.text:
I’ve tried to use Pluto on julia 1.6 and macos Catalina for a few times in the past weeks but it doesn’t precompile because MbedTLS doesn’t precompile.

Any similar experiences?

It seems that Pluto is not tested on julia nightly and macos.

Up to now, I’ve been successfully using it on 57 day old master for … well … 57 days.

messages.text: Hey Folks. so I saw that in many of the Pluto notebooks they begin by creating a temporary environment and directory and then installing packages into that temporary directory. package a lot, and installing it each time takes a long time. So just wanted to check.

messages.text: Is there a way to easily host a Pluto notebook somewhere, or do I need to deploy it with Kubernetes?

elements.text: Is there a way to easily host a Pluto notebook somewhere, or do I need to deploy it with Kubernetes?

messages.text:
What do think of this?
```### A Pluto.jl notebook ###
# v0.12.18

using Markdown
using InteractiveUtils

# ╔═╡ 2bc32b58-5195-11eb-1d7d-c56006dc6a50
using DataFrames

# ╔═╡ 3818791e-5195-11eb-1f64-b79c27fa617c
df = DataFrame(one = [10, 20, 30], two = ['a', 'b', 'c'], three = [:a, :b, :c])

# ╔═╡ 8149e030-5195-11eb-1841-c7d2f28b0017
df

# ╔═╡ 6d0664cc-5195-11eb-2841-6791abf86d39
select!(df, :three, :two, :one)

# ╔═╡ 5284ea64-5196-11eb-2583-57a8bdf3c0d5
select!(df, :two, :three, :one)

# ╔═╡ Cell order:
# ╠═2bc32b58-5195-11eb-1d7d-c56006dc6a50
# ╠═8149e030-5195-11eb-1841-c7d2f28b0017
# ╠═3818791e-5195-11eb-1f64-b79c27fa617c
# ╠═6d0664cc-5195-11eb-2841-6791abf86d39
# ╠═5284ea64-5196-11eb-2583-57a8bdf3c0d5```
The output of `df` depends on the order of execution.

elements.text: What do think of this?
The output of
df
depends on the order of execution.

messages.text: Pluto doesn’t really support mutating functions like that; instead, you can give the intermediates new names like in <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/564#issuecomment-708768065|https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/564#issuecomment-708768065> to help the dependency tracking, or just define + mutate the variable all in one cell, and then don’t mutate it later on

elements.text: Pluto doesn’t really support mutating functions like that; instead, you can give the intermediates new names like in
https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/564#issuecomment-708768065
to help the dependency tracking, or just define + mutate the variable all in one cell, and then don’t mutate it later on

messages.text:
Damn it, I thought I'm smart and beat the system, and load my dependencies as script nodes that have the source inlined (so that they survive static html export)...but pluto seems to specialize on that when loading scripts:
```// If there is no src="", we take the content and run it in an observablehq-like environment```
So, the dependencies don't get exported anymore...Does anyone have another idea for a workaround?

elements.text: Damn it, I thought I'm smart and beat the system, and load my dependencies as script nodes that have the source inlined (so that they survive static html export)...but pluto seems to specialize on that when loading scripts:
// If there is no src="", we take the content and run it in an observablehq-like environment
So, the dependencies don't get exported anymore...Does anyone have another idea for a workaround?

messages.text: Hello all! Is it somehow possible to turn a Pluto notebook into a fully interactive webpage to put on a website? Somewhere where the user could just manipulate sliders and change plots and parameters in a simulation. If possible, all on code running client-side with no servers?

messages.text:
What’s the best way to output an `md` string to a cell that I am programmatically constructing?  Right now I have a cell like the following:

```let
	msg = """
	Outputs by HTTP status:
	
	"""
	
	for (k, v) in status_split
		msg *= " -> $(k): **$(length(v))**\n"
	end
	msg
end```
But I can’t figure out how to get Pluto to believe that that’s markdown

elements.text: What’s the best way to output an
md
string to a cell that I am programmatically constructing?  Right now I have a cell like the following:

let
	msg = """
	Outputs by HTTP status:
	
	"""
	
	for (k, v) in status_split
		msg *= " -> $(k): **$(length(v))**\n"
	end
	msg
end
But I can’t figure out how to get Pluto to believe that that’s markdown

messages.text: and of course I figure it out immediately after I post for help; I should use `Markdown.parse(msg)`

elements.text: and of course I figure it out immediately after I post for help; I should use
Markdown.parse(msg)

messages.text:
Pluto actually has 63 themes via <@U01BU7WSP4Z>'s DarkMode!
I'd love to see these integrated in Pluto in the future, either via defining in Pluto.run(), or having a Toolbar(maybe make it a part of PlutoUI?)

Also, I wonder if DarkMode allows me to use the same themes for normal mode as well:slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: Hey folks. I ran into a new one and was not sure if anyone is tracking this. Has anyone tried using `Turing.jl` the Bayesian statistics package in Pluto. I was running a tutorial in pluto and I am getting a weird error where I believe that Pluto is having trouble displaying the output or something. The error presented itself as an MCMCChain error instead of a pluto error. I was just wondering if this was a known thing or if I should open a new issue. I did not want to add redundant issues if I can avoid it.

elements.text: Hey folks. I ran into a new one and was not sure if anyone is tracking this. Has anyone tried using
Turing.jl

the Bayesian statistics package in Pluto. I was running a tutorial in pluto and I am getting a weird error where I believe that Pluto is having trouble displaying the output or something. The error presented itself as an MCMCChain error instead of a pluto error. I was just wondering if this was a known thing or if I should open a new issue. I did not want to add redundant issues if I can avoid it.

messages.text:
Say, I find that whenever I use the command `Turing.turnprogress(false)`, I get an error message
```ERROR: UndefVarError: turnprogress not defined
Stacktrace:
 [1] getproperty(::Module, ::Symbol) at ./Base.jl:26
 [2] top-level scope at REPL[27]:1```
Does this make sense to anyone. I could not find a reference to `turnprogress` in the documentation, and no issues are posted. So perhaps I am missing something simple.

elements.text: Say, I find that whenever I use the command

turnprogress

messages.text: Okay all, I think this is the strangest error I've run into while coding in Julia.  When `using Pluto` inside a notebook, the notebook freezes without errors after it hits exactly 10 `@info` statements.  Could someone test this and let me know that I'm not crazy?

elements.text: Okay all, I think this is the strangest error I've run into while coding in Julia.  When
using Pluto
inside a notebook, the notebook freezes without errors after it hits exactly 10
@info
statements.  Could someone test this and let me know that I'm not crazy?

messages.text:
```# Cell 1
using Pluto

# Cell 2
for i in 1:20
    @info i 
end```

elements.text:
# Cell 1
using Pluto

# Cell 2
for i in 1:20
    @info i 
end

messages.text: I haven't used Pluto much since I submitted <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/372>, but opening it up again I see the "traffic light" for a selected cell now has this white line in it, instead of just being thicker like it was in that PR. Is that an intentional design choice made since then, or just some CSS quirk on my browser maybe?

messages.text: I'm seeing the notebook page itself become fairly unresponsive after working with it a while, particularly when generating plots over and over. Only affects the one notebook, others stay responsive. I'm curious if there's a loop running on the notebook process that's getting stretched too thin, or perhaps the script in the browser? I can investigate if I know where to look.
